case_title: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX vs BRINDAVAN HOTEL
complaint_summary: The Department alleged concealment of income by Brindavan Hotel based on suppression of sales, short-totalling in ledgers, and unaccounted payments discovered during a search of business premises.
investigation_summary: Search conducted on November 19, 1971 revealed discrepancies in books and vouchers, including suppression of sales amounting to Rs. 56,784 for 1970-71 and Rs. 52,308 for 1971-72. Income was estimated due to lack of reliable account books.
judgment_summary: The court reframed the question to determine whether the Tribunal was correct in holding no concealment of income despite suppression of sales. It declined to answer the reference directly, instructing the Tribunal to reconsider the explanation and evidence provided by the assessee regarding alleged concealment.
punishment: Penalty of Rs. 57,500 for 1970-71 and Rs. 62,941 for 1971-72 was initially levied but later cancelled by the Tribunal.
Decision_or_verdict: Reference answered accordingly; Tribunal instructed to rehear appeals and reconsider penalty in light of observations.
legal_arguments: Burden of proving conscious concealment lies with the Department.
Explanation under Section 271(1)(c) creates a rebuttable presumption of concealment.
Assessee argued understatement was due to employee mismanagement and external factors.
citations: CIT v. H. Abdul Bakshi and Brothers (1986) 160 ITR 94
CIT v. Mussadilal Ram Bharose (1987) 165 ITR 14
CIT v. Sait Khubchand Perumal (1988) 169 ITR 278
CIT v. Indian Molasses Co. (P.) Ltd. (1970) 78 ITR 474
key_issues: Whether suppression of sales constitutes concealment of income.
Applicability of Section 271(1)(c) and its Explanation.
Burden of proof regarding conscious concealment.

legal_provisions.explanation_to_section_271_1_c: Deeming provision for concealment if returned income is less than 80% of assessed income

court_observations.burden_of_proof: On the Department to prove conscious suppression
court_observations.assessee_explanation: Attributed understatement to employees but lacked evidence
court_observations.tribunal_action: Directed to rehear appeals and consider explanations

legal_terms.Concealment: Failure to disclose income or particulars of income.
legal_terms.Penalty: Punishment imposed for violation of tax laws.

words_and_phrases.Rebuttable Presumption: A presumption that can be challenged with evidence.
words_and_phrases.Gross or Wilful Neglect: Deliberate failure to comply with legal obligations.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around allegations of income concealment by Brindavan Hotel for assessment years 1970-71 and 1971-72. Despite evidence of suppressed sales and discrepancies in account books, the Tribunal cancelled penalties citing lack of proof of conscious concealment. The High Court reframed the question and instructed the Tribunal to reconsider the evidence and explanations provided by the assessee.
